awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: New Frontiers in Polar Coding: 5G and Beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
Since the first mobile phones became available in the 1980s, four distinct "generations" of wireless networks have been deployed to support reliable transmission of ever-increasing volumes of data to a growing number of users. What makes such reliable transmission of information possible are error-correcting codes, first conceived by Claude Shannon over 60 years ago. Polar coding is a key new error-correction technology introduced in the fifth wireless generation, known as 5G, that is currently being developed and standardized. Thus, soon enough, consumers the world over will all be using polar codes whenever making a phone call or accessing the Internet on a mobile device. Polar codes provably achieve the fundamental limits of communication established by Shannon in 1948, with low encoding and decoding complexity. Nevertheless, numerous challenges must be overcome in order to realize the full potential of polar coding in wireless communications. This project addresses these challenges to facilitate successful deployment of polar codes in 5G systems, while investigating fundamental problems in polar coding that lie beyond the 5G time horizon. These problems include polarization for time-varying channels and polar coding for channels with deletions. The results from this part of the investigation will contribute to the foundations of error-correction coding theory, and will also have an impact on adjacent scientific disciplines that are influenced by the polar-coding paradigm.

The discovery of channel polarization and polar codes is universally recognized as an historic breakthrough in coding theory. For short block lengths, polar codes under cyclic-redundancy-check-aided successive-cancellation list decoding are currently the best known coding scheme for binary-input Gaussian channels. Due to this and other considerations, 3GPP has decided to incorporate polar codes in the 5G wireless communications standard. The overarching goal in this project is to explore new frontiers in polar coding, thereby fundamentally advancing the current state-of-the-art in the field. Part of the research aims for immediately relevance to successful deployment of polar codes in 5G, whereas other parts focus on key theoretical problems in polar coding that lie beyond the 5G time-horizon. The specific objectives in this project are as follows: (1) Attain the gains of cyclic-redundancy-check-aided polar list-decoding with significantly lower complexity; (2) Construct practical universal polar codes that are not channel-dependent and provide near-optimal finite-length performance; (3) Develop code-domain multiple access techniques based on polar codes to enable massive connectivity; (4) Design and evaluate polar coding schemes for extended classes of channels, going well beyond the original memoryless and stationary set-up; (5) Extend the polarization paradigm and design polar codes for channels with deletions; (6) Develop a full-scale efficient, low-latency, and low-power system-on-chip implementation of polar list decoders. This project is a natural outgrowth of extensive and transformative prior work carried out by the investigators in polar coding.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Digital communication technologies have become an integral part of our daily lives, impacting various aspects of society, from personal communication over cellular phones to global communication networks connecting individuals and businesses worldwide. Error-correcting codes are among the fundamental components of any digital communication system, making reliable communication possible. Furthermore, advancements in coding theory, a field that studies error-correcting codes, have played a crucial role in the evolution of communication technologies. Currently, 5G systems are being deployed globally, with new features introduced in each release. Notably, channel coding techniques underwent a significant transformation in 5G compared to prior generations, with the deployment of polar codes as a key component ensuring reliable communication in 5G systems. From a theoretical perspective, the discovery of channel polarization theory and polar codes is universally recognized as a historic breakthrough in coding and information theory. In this project, our focus was on addressing and solving problems related to both the theory and practice of polar codes. We explored new frontiers in polar coding, with some aspects immediately relevant for the successful deployment of polar codes in 5G wireless systems, while others addressed key theoretical problems in polar coding with a longer time horizon.

Next, we provide a summary of our main technical findings.

In a major research direction, we focused on polar code design, decoding, and performance evaluation for low-capacity channels. We proposed a novel concatenation mechanism for polar-based codes to operate in very low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) regimes. In this scheme, the outer code is a hybrid polar code constructed in two stages, one with a binary kernel and another with a binary kernel applied over a binary extension field. In another work, we considered the straightforward polar-repetition scheme. We demonstrated that by carefully modifying the polarization kernel, while retaining a low-complexity encoder and decoder, we achieve a higher sum rate at each repeated block compared to the straightforward repetition scheme.

In another direction, focusing on non-stationary scenarios for communication channels, we presented a fast polarization scheme for an arbitrary sequence of such channels. We precisely defined and characterized the speed of polarization, establishing bounds on the resulting polarization process speed. Notably, this is the first result of this type for non-stationary scenarios.

We also explored novel applications of polar coding in security, privacy, and distributed learning. We proposed protocols for secret key generation in static environments where the physical layer characteristics, as the primary source of common randomness, are mostly static. While various linear codes could be used for key reconciliation, we demonstrated that polar codes, with their low-complexity encoding and decoding algorithms and natural nested structure, provide superior performance. We also proposed a threshold-secure coding scheme based on recursive Kronecker-type structures, the basis of both polar codes and closely related Reed-Muller (RM) codes. These were then shown to meet the security and reliability conditions of practical systems. Additionally, motivated by numerically stable coded computing, we considered a framework where real-valued data is encoded using the generator matrix of binary linear codes. We developed a low-complexity algorithm for decoding polar codes and their subcodes, such as Reed-Muller (RM) codes, over real-valued erasure channels. Extensive numerical analysis of RM- and polar-coded computing schemes demonstrated their advantages in achieving close-to-optimal performance. We also developed new polar-based coding schemes with sparsity constraints on their generator matrices, proven to be critical factors in certain emerging applications of codes, e.g., distributed crowdsourcing schemes.

In another direction, we designed new machine learning-based codes and decoders in polar code families. In one work, we considered the recently proposed recursive projection-aggregation (RPA) algorithm for decoding closely related Reed-Muller (RM) codes. We proposed a variation of it, named subRPA, to reduce the complexity of the decoding algorithm by pruning the set of projections pursued during the decoding process. We then derived a soft-decision-based version of our algorithm, enabling the training of a machine learning (ML) model to search for good sets of projections to minimize the decoding error rate. In another work, we constructed Kronecker Operation (KO) codes, a computationally efficient family of deep-learning-driven (encoder, decoder) pairs that outperformed their classical linear counterparts, i.e., polar and RM codes, on canonical Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) channels.

Finally, we designed new polar-based recursive structures for non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) schemes. In particular, we developed a novel approach to construct code-domain NOMA by designing resource allocation pattern matrices when the number of resource elements is strictly smaller than the number of users. Inspired by the recursive structure of the polarization transform, we constructed specific pattern matrices by utilizing the Kronecker product of several other factor matrices, each with a smaller dimension. We also leveraged the recursive structure of designed pattern matrices to develop a low-complexity and efficient detection algorithm for the sequence of mixed symbols received at the receiver.
